meanings.def: the part of the face that sticks out above the mouth, used for breathing and smelling things
examples: She had dark eyes and a long narrow nose.
He broke his nose in the fight.
She wrinkled her nose in disgust.
He pressed his nose up against the window.
through your nose Try to breathe through your nose.
He blew his nose (= cleared it by blowing strongly into a handkerchief).
a blocked/runny nose
Stop picking your nose! (= removing dirt from it with your finger)
He held his nose as he passed the stinking dustbins.
(figurative) He held his nose and voted for the bill anyway.
He pushed his glasses up the bridge of his nose (= the hard part near the top).
Who knows what the future will bring?
Breathe in through your nose and out through your mouth.
Cats have very sensitive noses and rely heavily on scent markings.
Charlie pressed his nose against the window.
He stuck his bulbous red nose back into his pint of beer.
He tapped his nose in a knowing gesture.
His nose wrinkled with distaste.
I had to wear a black moustache and false nose for the role.
She dressed up as a clown with a white face and red nose.
She walked with her shoulders back and her nose pointing skyward.
She was weeping loudly and her nose was running.
She wrinkled her nose as if she had just smelled a bad smell.
The boy sat there with his finger up his nose.
The dog pushed its wet nose into my palm.
The sharp nose and thin lips gave his face a very harsh look.
a child with a runny nose

meanings.def: having the type of nose mentioned
examples: red-nosed
large-nosed

meanings.def: the front part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.
examples: Heat detectors are fitted in the nose of the missile.
He pushed the nose down for the final approach.
The plane's nose dipped as it started descending towards the runway.

meanings.def: a special ability for finding or recognizing something
examples: As a journalist, she has always had a nose for a good story.

meanings.def: a sense of smell
examples: a dog with a good nose
(figurative) Good noses can always smell a fight brewing.

meanings.def: a smell that is characteristic of a particular wine
examples: This Cote de Beaune has a good nose, with apricot and raisin aromas.

meanings.def: by only a small amount (used mostly when talking about horse racing)
examples: He lost his first race by a nose but won the next three.
Glen's Diamond was declared the winner by a nose from the 11–4 favourite.

meanings.def: to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm somebody else but that also harms you
to be guided by your sense of smell
to go straight forward
examples: The garage is a mile ahead up the hill—just follow your nose.

meanings.def: to act according to what seems right or reasonable, rather than following any particular rules
if you say that people have their noses in the trough, you mean that they are trying to get a lot of money for themselves
to annoy somebody
to defeat somebody
examples: We have to give him a bloody nose in the election.
Voters gave the government a bloody nose in the local elections.

meanings.def: to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

meanings.def: to be reading something and giving it all your attention
examples: Peter always has his nose in a book.

meanings.def: to look around a place; to look for something in a place
examples: I’ll have a nose round and see what I can find.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody is not upset or annoyed about something because it does not affect them in a bad way
to avoid doing anything wrong or illegal
examples: Since leaving prison, he's managed to keep his nose clean.

meanings.def: to try not to become involved in things that should not really involve you
to work hard for a long period of time without stopping
to make somebody do everything you want; to control somebody completely
to behave in a way that suggests that you think that you are better than somebody or that something is not good enough for you
examples: People who live in that area tend to look down their noses at their poorer neighbours.
They tend to look down their noses at people who drive small cars.

meanings.def: if cars, etc. are nose to tail, they are moving slowly in a long line with little space between them
examples: The traffic was nose to tail for miles.

meanings.def: exactly
examples: The budget should hit the $136 billion target on the nose.

meanings.def: to pay too much money for something
very obvious
to try to become involved in something that should not involve you
examples: He’s always poking his nose into other people’s business.

meanings.def: a polite way of referring to the fact that a woman is going to the toilet
examples: I'm just going to powder my nose.

meanings.def: to upset or annoy somebody, especially by not giving them enough attention
to keep reminding somebody in an unkind way of their past mistakes
to make a rude sign with your thumb on your nose; to show that you have no respect for somebody/something
examples: The company just thumbs its nose at the legislation on pollution.
They thumb their noses at all of our traditions.

meanings.def: to refuse something, especially because you do not think that it is good enough for you
examples: The children turn up their noses at almost everything I cook.

meanings.def: if something is under somebody’s nose, it is very close to them but they cannot see it
examples: I searched everywhere for the letter and it was under my nose all the time!

meanings.def: if something happens under somebody’s nose, they do not notice it even though it is not being done secretly
examples: The police didn't know the drugs ring was operating right under their noses.

meanings.def: in a way that is not friendly and suggests that you think that you are better than other people
examples: She walked in with her nose in the air, ignoring everyone.

idioms.def: by only a small amount (used mostly when talking about horse racing)
examples: He lost his first race by a nose but won the next three.
Glen's Diamond was declared the winner by a nose from the 11–4 favourite.

idioms.idiom: cut off your nose to spite your face
idioms.def: to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm somebody else but that also harms you
to be guided by your sense of smell
examples: The garage is a mile ahead up the hill—just follow your nose.

idioms.idiom: get/have your nose/snout in the trough
idioms.def: if you say that people have their noses in the trough, you mean that they are trying to get a lot of money for themselves
to annoy somebody
to defeat somebody
examples: We have to give him a bloody nose in the election.
Voters gave the government a bloody nose in the local elections.

idioms.idiom: have your head/nose in a book
idioms.def: to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

idioms.def: to be reading something and giving it all your attention
examples: Peter always has his nose in a book.

idioms.def: to look around a place; to look for something in a place
examples: I’ll have a nose round and see what I can find.

idioms.idiom: it’s no skin off my, your, his, etc. nose
idioms.def: used to say that somebody is not upset or annoyed about something because it does not affect them in a bad way
to avoid doing anything wrong or illegal
examples: Since leaving prison, he's managed to keep his nose clean.

idioms.idiom: keep your nose out of something
idioms.def: to try not to become involved in things that should not really involve you

idioms.idiom: keep your nose to the grindstone
idioms.def: to work hard for a long period of time without stopping
to make somebody do everything you want; to control somebody completely

idioms.idiom: look down your nose at somebody/something
idioms.def: to behave in a way that suggests that you think that you are better than somebody or that something is not good enough for you
examples: People who live in that area tend to look down their noses at their poorer neighbours.
They tend to look down their noses at people who drive small cars.

idioms.def: if cars, etc. are nose to tail, they are moving slowly in a long line with little space between them
examples: The traffic was nose to tail for miles.

idioms.def: exactly
examples: The budget should hit the $136 billion target on the nose.

idioms.def: to pay too much money for something

idioms.idiom: (as) plain as a pikestaff | (as) plain as day | (as) plain as the nose on your face
idioms.def: very obvious
to try to become involved in something that should not involve you
examples: He’s always poking his nose into other people’s business.

idioms.def: a polite way of referring to the fact that a woman is going to the toilet
examples: I'm just going to powder my nose.

idioms.idiom: put somebody’s nose out of joint
idioms.def: to upset or annoy somebody, especially by not giving them enough attention
to keep reminding somebody in an unkind way of their past mistakes
to make a rude sign with your thumb on your nose; to show that you have no respect for somebody/something
examples: The company just thumbs its nose at the legislation on pollution.
They thumb their noses at all of our traditions.

idioms.idiom: turn your nose up at something
idioms.def: to refuse something, especially because you do not think that it is good enough for you
examples: The children turn up their noses at almost everything I cook.

idioms.def: if something is under somebody’s nose, it is very close to them but they cannot see it
examples: I searched everywhere for the letter and it was under my nose all the time!
The police didn't know the drugs ring was operating right under their noses.

idioms.idiom: with your nose in the air
idioms.def: in a way that is not friendly and suggests that you think that you are better than other people
examples: She walked in with her nose in the air, ignoring everyone.

meanings.def: to move forward slowly and carefully
examples: + adv./prep. The plane nosed down through the thick clouds.
He nosed the boat slowly across the water.
nose your way + adv./prep. The taxi nosed its way back into the traffic.

meanings.def: to search for something or push something with its nose
examples: Dogs nosed around in piles of refuse.
